clinical_study.brief_title: Caregiving Needs of Older Adults With Cancer Post Hospital Discharge
clinical_study.official_title: Caregiving Needs of Older Adults With Cancer at 1-week Post Hospital Discharge

brief_summary.textblock: The goals of the study are to investigate the needs of caregivers in caring for older adults (65+) with cancer at 1-week of hospital discharge and to explore strategies that may assist caregivers in their home caregiving needs. The study will enroll older cancer patients and their caregivers admitted to 9100 and 9300, which are hematological and non-hematological malignancy units at Duke University Medical Center (DUMC) respectively. Findings derived from this study will inform the development of interventions for better discharge preparation of caregivers for home caregiving. Additionally, the study has the potential to reduce non- emergent use of acute healthcare services through caregiver support and education.

detailed_description.textblock: Baseline demographic data about the caregiver and patient will be collected at patient beside prior to hospital discharge. Qualitative interviews will be conducted with the cancer caregivers in their home at 1-week after their loved one was discharged from the hospital, and at 2-weeks after discharge from the hospital. This is a qualitative study that will utilize a qualitative descriptive method.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 week after patient discharge from hospital
primary_outcome.description: Describe needs of caregivers caring for an older adult with cancer at home during the first week of hospital discharge, as measured by coded interview.

primary_outcome.measure: Caregiver strategies assisting in caregiving role
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 week after patient discharge from hospital
primary_outcome.description: Explore from caregivers strategies that may assist them in their caregiving during the first week of hospital discharge (including, but not limited to, managing patient symptoms), as measured by coded interview.

primary_outcome.measure: Caregiver decision making in seeking assistance for cancer patient
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 week after patient discharge from hospital
primary_outcome.description: Describe the process used by caregivers in deciding when to seek assistance for care of their loved ones once discharged from the hospital, as measured by coded interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Challenges or successes in caring for loved one since first interview
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2 weeks after patient discharge from the hospital
secondary_outcome.description: At 2 weeks a second qualitative interview will be conducted with the cancer caregivers. The purpose of this interview is to clarify any statements made in the first interview, and identify any additional challenges faced in caregiving, or any aspects of caregiving that have become easier for the caregiver. This will be measured by the coding in the interviews.

study_pop.textblock: Subjects include 30 informal caregivers and cancer patients dyads. Patients have been admitted to either the hematological malignancy unit, or the non-hematological malignancy unit for treatment of cancer, or treatment-related/cancer-related complications.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The caregiver must co-reside with the cancer patient
- Caregiver must speak English
- Caregiver must be at least 18 years of age
- Patients must be 65 years of age or older
- Patients must have been admitted to either the 9100 or 9300 oncology unit for treatment of cancer, or treatment-related/cancer-related complications
- Patients must be discharged home to participate in the study
- Dyads must live within a 30-mile radius of Duke University Medical Center
Exclusion Criteria:
- Dyads who received hospice referral prior to the care recipient's discharge
- Patient must not have any diagnosis of dementia in their medical records, or any cognitive impairment as assessed by hospital providers (physicians and nurses)
